# To be done
* Treemap comparing overall composition of Johor vs Singapore (better than the bargraphs)
* Regroup Singapore and Raffles Marina for the barplots (Figure \@ref(fig:treemap))
* Do the plot of the different species as a function of the monsoon  (Figure \@ref(fig:mamiello) and following)

# Methodology
* For assignation with Wang assigner, only ASVs with bootstrap at super group level taked into account
* Metazoa and Fungi not taken into account
* Abundant" OTUs are more than 10% in at least one sample
* Some samples for which the quality of sequencing was bad have been removed (Caroline list)
* Samples have been normalized to the medium number of reads for the group considered (e.g. for all eukaryotes or for all photosynthetic eukaryotes)

# Basic statistics
* 663 ASVs of which 267 are autotrophs
* 81 samples

```{r dinos, fig.cap="Localization of major Dinophyceae species",  fig.align = "center", out.width ="80%"}
 knitr::include_graphics("Metabarcoding_Singapore_ASV_files/figure-html/bar_plot_species-2.png", dpi=72)
```

```{r diatoms, fig.cap="Localization of major diatoms species",  fig.align = "center", out.width ="80%"}
 knitr::include_graphics("Metabarcoding_Singapore_ASV_files/figure-html/bar_plot_species-3.png", dpi=72)
```

* Dinoflagellates are dominating followed by diatoms  (Figure \@ref(fig:treemap))
* Among the key genera/species there are clear differences between Johor and Singapore (Raffles should merged with Singapore probably for this kind of comparison)
    * Dinos  (Figure \@ref(fig:dinos)): *Gyrodinium fusiforme* (Johor), *Gyrodinium gutrula*; *Woloszeunskia halophila* (Johor), *Karlodinium veneficum* (Singapore)
    * Diatoms  (Figure \@ref(fig:diatoms)): Most diatoms are on the Johor side except for *Leptocylindrus*, *Chaetoceros* (endosymbiont), *Cyclotella* (Johor), *Carataulina* (Johor), *Thalassiosira*, *Shionodiscus*
    * Chlorophyta  (Figure \@ref(fig:chlorophyta) and  \@ref(fig:mamiello)): *Nanochloris* (*Picochlorum*, mostly in Johor), *Micromonas* clade A.ABC.1-2 (M. commoda, mostly Singapore), *Micromonas* clade lagoons (in fact we call it warm now, mostly Singapore), *Ostreococcus* clade A (*lucimarinus*, mostly)
    * Crypto   (Figure \@ref(fig:heatmap)): *Geminigera* (Singapore)

* It is surprising that we do not find any Ochrophyta besides the diatoms : no Pelago, no Dictyo is it a problem with the primers ?
* For the Mamiellophyceae, necessary to align with Margot V4 alignements to check exactly the signatures.

# Effect of different factors on eukaryote composition

```{r effect-strait, fig.cap="Effect of strait on overall eukaryote composition",  fig.align = "center", out.width ="50%", fig.show = 'hold'}
 knitr::include_graphics("Metabarcoding_Singapore_ASV_files/figure-html/bar_plot_factors-2.png", dpi=72)
```
```{r effect-station, fig.cap="Effect of station on overall eukaryote composition",  fig.align = "center", out.width ="50%"}
 knitr::include_graphics("Metabarcoding_Singapore_ASV_files/figure-html/bar_plot_factors-5.png", dpi=72)
```
```{r effect-monsoon, fig.cap="Effect of monsoon on overall eukaryote composition",  fig.align = "center", out.width ="50%"}
 knitr::include_graphics("Metabarcoding_Singapore_ASV_files/figure-html/bar_plot_factors-8.png", dpi=72)
```

* Radiolaria, Cryptophyta, Ciliophora, Cercozoa only found in Singapore strait and Raffles (Figure \@ref(fig:effect-strait))
* Monsoon has less effect on the overall composition... (Figure \@ref(fig:effect-monsoon))

Query: should we do just on the Photosynthetic eukaryotes or all eukaryotes ?

```{r nmds-photo, fig.cap="NMDS - Photosynthetic  eukaryotes",  fig.align = "center", out.width ="80%"}
 knitr::include_graphics("Metabarcoding_Singapore_ASV_files/figure-html/nmds_all-5.png", dpi=72)
```
* The strait seems to be most discriminant factor (Figure \@ref(fig:nmds-prok)).  
* However it is interesting that for eukaryotes (Figure \@ref(fig:nmds-euk)) Raffles Marina seems to be clustering with Singapore straight rather than Johor most of the time while for prokaryotes (Figure \@ref(fig:nmds-prok)), Raffles is clearly in between.  Probably an interesting point to discuss.
